No one would blame Ric Furrer for not using Facebook, but if someone who works with information decides not to use it, people think they’re weird (I know this from my own experience). 

Even though it’s not always obvious, deep work can still bring a lot of satisfaction in jobs that deal with information, just like it does in hands-on jobs. In this chapter, I want to show you that deep work is valuable. I’ll make three points to support this idea. These points will go from specific to more general: starting with how our brains work, then looking at our feelings, and finally discussing bigger ideas. I’ll explain that no matter how you look at deep work, choosing to focus deeply can give you the same sense of meaning that craftsmen like Ric Furrer experience. So, the main idea of this chapter is that living deeply isn’t just good for making money; it’s also a fulfilling way to live.

A Neurological Argument for Depth

Winifred Gallagher, a science writer, discovered a link between paying attention and being happy after she got a scary cancer diagnosis—“not just cancer,” she points out, “but a really bad kind.” In her 2009 book, Rapt, she remembers walking out of the hospital after the diagnosis and suddenly realizing, “This disease wants all my attention, but I’m going to focus on my life instead.” The cancer treatment was tough, but Gallagher noticed that by focusing on the good things in her life—like movies, walks, and a 6:30 martini—she felt surprisingly okay. Even though she should have been scared and sad, she found her life was often quite nice.

Curious about this, Gallagher wanted to learn more about how attention—what we choose to focus on and what we ignore—affects our quality of life. After five years of reporting on science, she believed she found a “grand unified theory” of the mind: different fields like anthropology, education, behavioral economics, and family counseling all suggest that managing our attention well is essential for a good life and can improve almost every part of it.

**PAGE SUMMARY:** This passage discusses how deep work can lead to a fulfilling life, comparing it to hands-on jobs. It highlights Winifred Gallagher's experience with cancer and how focusing on positive aspects improved her happiness, suggesting that managing attention is key to a good life.
